This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE JAPANESE FLEET.
div.p: Among the most interesting items of tele graphic news that have arrived this morning, is the information that the large majority of the Russian men-of-war sunk at Port Arthur are far less damaged than was anticipated, and will be perfectly serviceable when raised. The Peresvirat, the Bayan, and the Pallada have already been floated. The Varyak and Novik, victims of the combats of Chemulpho and Aniwa, are also in Japanese hands, and the "crowning mercy" of Tsusima gave Admiral Togo four armoured ships to add to his fleet and in some degree replace the lost Hatsuse and Yashima. Meantime two armoured cruisers of a type indistinguishable from battleships have been laid down in Japan and are progressing rapidly. Twenty-five tor pedo boat destroyers, ten torpedo-boats, and several submarines are on the stocks, and the Katori and Kashima, vessels that can fairly be compared with the King Edward VII., will be delivered at the end of the war. Three huge vessels of a new and superlatively power ful type have also been ordered, and there is no question that in a year's time no Pacific squadron, except perhaps that of the United States of America, will compare with the fleet that will fly the Rising Sun.

England has had the good sense to recognise the imminence of this change and to show her complete confidence in her ally by removing her ironclad squadron to European waters. The seven battleships recalled from China are to add to the strength of the European fleets of Great Britain. Four of them will join the Channel, late Home, Squadron, which will soon number 15 battleships, while the other three will increase the Atlantic Fleet, the Mediterranean Fleet, and the commissioned Reserve. In future the Eastern fleet will consist of three groups of cruisers and be based on Hong Kong, Aden, and Sydney.

The action of the British Government clearly shows that the prophecies of certain publicists, that Japan would be embroiled after the war with the English-speaking Powers, are not likely to be fulfilled in our own case. England hands over the control of the China Seas to her ally-that is all. As to the relations of other Powers with the new mistress of the Pacific, we greatly doubt whether any of the Continental States will dream of attempting to compete with Japan in Eastern waters, or of impeding Japan's action in China. As for America, the two countries are at present on friendly terms, but we wonder how soon the Japanese will resent the threatened exclusion of their compatriots from California, Hawaii, and the Philippines. There is the danger point,-if the Australian and American de mocracies insist on excluding Japanese immigrants or throwing restrictions on their immigration which are not applied to the majority of the low-class Europeans who go to the Commonwealth or the Republic, they may some day have to face the yellow world armed, [illegible]kless and terrible. If, on the contrary, they decide on a liberal policy restricting only the immigration of the ignorant, the diseased, and the criminal, and abandon that colour-prejudice which is such an amazing feature in the most advanced modern demo cracies, the peace of the Pacific is assured for half a century to come.

div.head:
VLADIVOSTOK IN PERIL.
JAPS LAND TO THE NORTH.
RUSSIAN STAND AT SAGHALIEN.

div.p: It is reported here that the army has actually landed to the north of Vladivostok.
(Reuter.)

After a series of defeats at Saghalien the Russians are making a stand at Mauka, where the topography prevents further retreat north- wards. The shortness of supplies will probably soon oblige them to surrender.
(Reuter.)
Admiral Kamimura's destroyer flotilla is bombarding the Russians at Youkiman.

div.head:
RUSSIAN SHIPS AT PORT ARTHUR
PERFECTLY SERVICEABLE

div.p: The large majority of the Russian men-of- war sunk at Port-Arthur are far less damaged than was anticipated. They will be perfectly serviceable when repaired.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE PEACE CONFERENCE.
RUSSIA AND CHINA'S INTERESTS.

div.p: In reply to China's notification of the 12th inst., Russia says that as the war is between Russia and Japan, peace will be negotiated by Russo-Japanese plenipotentiaries. Nevertheless Russia, who is in relations of friendship with China, recognises that the latter is interested in certain questions which are to be discussed.
(Reuter.)

The Governor ordered a conference of the commercial and industrial societies to break up on the ground that they were discussing politics. The conference ignored the order and passed a resolution approving the Zemstvoist programme for a Constitution.
(Reuter.)
The great Congress of the Zemstvos has begun without the police interfering.
(Reuter.)
The Congress of delegates from the Zemstvos has been opened at the house of Prince Dolgovoukoff.
(Havas.)
Mutinies continue among the sailors of the Baltic, notwithstanding official denials.

Reuter's Agency learns from Fez that the French, British, and Spanish Ministers are now co-operating with a view to obtaining the Sultan's approval to a Conference. M. St. René-Taillandier and Count Tattenbach have exchanged visits, and the personal relations between the two missions are now unstrained.
(Reuter.)
The crisis in Hungary has culminated in the opposition issuing a manifesto to the country urging the people to refuse to pay taxes and to do military service.
(Reuter.)

div.head: LEON FEHMY ARRESTED.-
div.p: M. Leon Fehmy, the editor of "La Justice," has been arrested. He is accused of first attempting to blackmail Orphi Pasha and then of assaulting him in his house.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.-
div.p: We may remind our Alexandria readers of the children's ball which is to take place at the Casino to-morrow, and which promises to be an enjoyable function.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: -9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 17th inst., all of which were British ships. The day's receipts were frs. 249,728.64 making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,921,710.95.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.-
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that owing to a case of plague having been discovered at Adalia, arrivals from that port are subjected to 48 hours observation and disinfection.

div.head: THE GIRGEH SCANDAL.-
div.p: The appeal of Hassan Bey Wassif, ex-Moudir of Ghirgeh, will be heard by the Court of Cassation on August 1. The appeal has been presented by Omar Bey Loutfi, till lately sub-director of the Khe divial Law School.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.-
div.p: We are asked to remove an impression which apparently exists, that the charges at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, are high. We understand that rooms may be had from P.T. 40 upwards, special apart ments being of course charged a higher rate.

div.head: SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE.-
div.p: Nine candidates who have finished their studies this year at the 'School of Agriculture' have received their diploma. M. Aristidi Angeletto, M. Missak Yakoubian, and Hussein Effendi Wali have won the first three places in the examination.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.-
div.p: The French comedy company occupying the boards of the Alhambra are having a successful run. A mixed pro gramme is announced for to-night, and to morrow night the clever artiste M. Stintzy takes his "benefit" with Le Bossu, ou Le Petit Parisien.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM.-
div.p: The hours of the Greco-Roman Museum have been changed as follows: 9. a.m. to noon and 4 to 6 p.m. On Wednesdays the museum is closed all day. The hours of admission to the Pompey's Pillar excavations and Kom-el-Shougafa re main unchanged, i.e., from 9 a.m. till sunset.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-
div.p: We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual sub scription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: NEW SYSTEM OF ARTESIAN WELL.-
div.p: Mr. G. N. Perrakis of Alexandria has invented a new system of artesian well superior to any other system, owing to its perfection and power of resistance, being constructed with the best material and capable of increasing instead of decreasing the supply of water. One of the kind was constructed on the estate of Messrs N. and A. Sursock, and has been patented to avoid imitations. Mr. Perrakis has procured special tools for boring and digging earth of any kind, above 2,000 feet. For hitherto uncultivated lands he accepts the value of the work in land. He has a stock of steam engines, mills, ice-making machines, aerated water plant, tambours (Archimedean screws), sakkiehs, weighing-machines, pumps and accessories, etc. Repairs of machinery also undertaken.

div.head:
EGYTIAN ESTATES.
STATUTORY MEETING-OBJECTS AND PROSPECTS OF THE CO.
div.p: The statutory meeting of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, was held yesterday week at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, London, E.C., Mr. Greville Horsley Palmer(chairman of the company) presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. Sydney William Bart man) having read the notice calling the meeting,

The Chairman said: This is, as you are aware, the statutory general meeting, and you have in your hands the accounts up to April 20th which the Act of Parliament says we must present to you. I have really very little to say. These statutory meetings have been provided by the Acts of Parliament, and all sorts of conditions have been made as to what we are to tell you. I suppose they are devised for the protection of share- holders, but, personally, I do not see how a meeting held under these circumstances can be much protection. The accounts before you are made up to April 30th-a date when the company was in an embryo state, when even the payments on allotment were not complete, and when we had not commenced the investment of even the small portion of funds we had in our hands at that time. I sup pose, at any rate, it gives one an opportunity of seeing the shareholders and having a talk to them, and I wish there were more present, but those who are not present will have the opportunity of reading what I have said. You know there were a good many companies of this kind started much about the same time as we did, and many of the chairmen of these companies have thought fit to indulge in rather extravagant prophecies as to the future of their companies, but this is a course which I do not propose to take. I am rather of the opinion of the American writer who said "Never prophesy unless you know." I do not know anything about the future of this company, but what I do know is that the capital of the company was more than fully subscribed by responsible people and our preliminary expenses were ridiculously small, that no promotion money was paid, and that therefore the whole of the capital of the com pany, with trifling reductions, is available for the purpose of the business. In order to obtain that business we have taken the trouble to get the very best advice we possible can. You will, of course, not expect me to go into the details of the business, but I will say that so far the funds of the company have been employed in a very admirable manner. Mr. Lang Anderson, who is one of our prin ciple advisers in Egypt, is a gentleman who is a very successful worker in all matters connect ed with land investment in Egypt, and we rely very much on his advice. We are all striving to work together to obtain the best results possible for the shareholders. The principle we have laid down is that no ivest ment of a large sum should be made without our being consulted on this side, and so far as we have gone there has not been any conflict of opinion as to the desirability of any of the transactions into which we have entered. If we continue to work together as harmoni ously in future as we have hitherto the results cannot fail to be satisfactory to you. I have been told, with what truth I do not know, that we have been blamed in some quarter in Egypt-not on this side-for keeping the control too much in our own hands, and we have been told that we may lose opportunities of picking up advantageous bargains because time would be lost in communicating with London. If that is so, I cannot help it. Directors year by year have more and more responsibilities thrown upon them by Act of Parliament, and we are bound to protect our selves, and in so doing protect you. If your interests suffer from excess of caution you will at any rate not be able to blame us in that respect. Our policy has been deliberately adopted, and we are not inclined to alter it at present, at all events until we see how we are getting on. I may be expected, perhaps, to give you some idea of the nature of our business. The investment of capital in Egypt is mainly connected with agricultural land, and since the British occupation a wave of prosperity has set in, and I see no reason to doubt it will continue. The native population are realising that life and property are now secure, and the hoarding of money, which was so prevalent in the days of former Khedives is being discontinued. Money is being brought out for the improvement and development of the country, and the natives themselves enter very largely into compe tition in the real estate market. This gives facili ty, and will give facility for some time to come, for the profitable employment of capital in all matters connected with land and agriculture. By this I do not mean gambling in real estate, but it will doubtless often be possible to pick up bargains in land and property with a view to reselling. This, however, I trust, will be the exception. Our idea is to employ our money in loans and mortgages and enterprises that will be bringing in immediate returns, and not to lock it up for years in land speculation. That is the general trend of our business and beyond that I am not prepared to go into further details, though if there are questions which any shareholder wishes to ask I shall be pleased to answer. I now move the adoption of the report and accounts.
Sir John Heron Maxwell seconded the resolu tion, and it was carried unanimously.
A special meeting was afterwards held, at which certain modifications of the articles of association to meet the views of the Committee of the Stock Exchange were formally agreed to.
On the motion of Mr. J. Rupert Campball a vote of thanks was passed to the chairman.

div.head:
ANFOUCHY BAY.
RECLAMATION PROPOSAL.
div.p: Our readers may be interested to hear that a well-known Alexandrian land-owner is about to propose to the Government an undertaking that will add about a million square metres to the amount of land available for building at Alexandria. The idea of filling up a large part of the shallow Anfouchy Bay and a small section of the Eastern harbour, and using the land thus reclaimed from the sea for building purposes, is most suggestive, and should the proposal be entertained by the Government, and finally carried out, we imagine that rents, which are just now ridicul ously high, will be brought down to juster proportions-if the Government only exercises a little care in drawing up the terms of the concession.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The following report, showing the number of feddans of cotton cultivations which have been attacked by the cotton worm and the work which has been done for its destruction during the week ending 15th inst., has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior:-
Ghizeh:-In this province 3,144 feddans, belonging to 1,700 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared of the worm by 3,119 children.
Kalioubieh:-2,879 feddans, belonging to 1,066 proprietors, have been attacked and 3,243 (?) have been cleared by 14, 842 children.
Menoufieh:-3,222 feddans, belonging to 898 proprietors, have been attacked and 2,991 of these have been cleared by 12,674 children.
Gharbieh:-4,839 feddans, belonging to 874 proprietors, have been attacked and 4,443 feddans have been cleared by 6,870 children.
Sarkieh:-1,953 feddans, belonging to 344 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 5,859 children.
Behera:-43,589 fedans, belonging to 5,407 proprietors, have been attacked and 31,963 feddans have been cleared by 97,005 children.
Dakahlieh:-9,163 feddans, belonging to 2,392 proprietors, have been attacked and 8,229 feddans have been cleared by 26, 281 children.
Fayoum:-10 feddans, belonging to 2 pro prietors, have been attacked and cleared by 345 children.
Minieh:-3 feddans, belonging to 3 pro prietors, have been attacked and cleared by 361 children.
Beni-Souef:-1 feddan, belonging to 1 pro prietor, has been attacked and cleared.
Damietta:-142 feddans, belonging to 65 pro prietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 896 children.

It is noticeable that in certain provinces the number of feddans which have been attacked has decreased whilst in other provinces an increase in numbers is reported, but it is expected that next week's report will show a general diminution

July is as a rule a criminal month in our province, for the fellah has little work to do, and is, in consequence, on the alert to avenge the misdeeds of others or to commit fresh crimes himself. I understand that eight crimes took place last week in the Tahta district, of which the following was certainly the most curious.

Two sheikhs were teaching some religious subject in a mosque at Tema. They had many hearers. After a while they disputed over the proper interpretation of a passage, had a sharp quarrel, and were only calmed by the efforts of their audience. But this calm was not of long duration, for one of the sheikhs went to his house and returned with a revolver with which he shot his rival as he passed him in the street. The wound was fortunately not mortal and one of the sheikhs is now in gaol, while the other remains in hospital.

On Sunday night the two brothers of a woman who had been three years a widow fell upon her and strangled her in their house at El Tawader village in the Baliana Markaz. It appears that she had a suitor, who was not "a Hawary" i.e., of pure Arab descent, being but a mere fellah. Her brothers refused his affinity and having suspicions concerning the relations of their sister with her suitor trangled her in the night. Both have been arrested.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Dundee, from Glasgow, Gibraltar, and Malta, with general cargo and coals, left the latter port Wednesday and is due at Alexandria Sunday morning.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria at 10 p.m. on Tuesday.

div.head: GERMANY IN EGYPT.
ENGLISH "PERSECUTION"
div.p: The "Neue Preussiche Kreuz Zeitung" is by no means pleased with the tone of the questions asked in Parliament re the formation of a German steamer service on the Nile. Our contemporary writes:-Wherever German trade and German shipping appear in the world's market they are assailed and persecuted by the English. The news that a German S.S. Company was about to start a Nile service drove Lord Muskerry to ask the Government if the report was really true. It almost seems that the people in England regard Egypt as an integral part of the British Empire, though the country is in reality a tributary State of the Ottoman Empire. It was emphatically stated in that much quoted Anglo-French Agreement of April 8, 1904, that, as in Morocco, no political changes should be made in Egypt. The annexation of Egypt by England is therefore forbidden. The Capitulations remain in force and the "most-favored nation" clause operates in the country's commercial relations. On account of this clause no opposition can be made to the appearance of a German shipping company on the scene and to its starting a river service on the Nile, however bitterly the English may discuss the matter.

A Government notice of the 11 inst. includes Alexandria in the list of "infected places," against which quarantine measures are applied. Vessels from infected places not having on board an actual case of cholera, yellow fever or plague, when arriving within 10 days from date of departure, are allowed to load in quaran tine. Vessels from infected places will be admitted to pratique after 10 days from date of departure.

Several complaints have reached us with regard to the promiscuous unloading of boats along the Mahmoudieh Canal in defiance of the regulations, which only permit the un loading of boats, barges, etc., at certain special points near the Gabbari bridge.

A correspondent writes:-A few days ago a boat unloaded in this way near the Serai Sofia, about theree minutes' walk from the tram terminus at Moharrem Bey. A whole cargo of earth was landed, which produced an immense amount of dust, almost blinding the passers-by and annoying residents of houses in the locality. Some of the house-owners of the neighborhood complained at the caracol at Moharrem Bey, but in spite of the orders of the moawen nothing was done to prevent this breach of the regulations. The policemen start ed on his errand but did nothing. Naturally the boatmen were encouraged by their freedom from interference and yesterday another boat began to unload a cargo of straw at the same place. So many people use the canal road on the banks of the Mahmoudieh as a prome nade that the Alexandrian public, which deserves some consideration, counts on the effective aid of the police in putting a stop to this nuisance.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: During the absence of Mrt. Clowes, Mr. Verschoyle will act as Inspector-General of Irrigation for Upper Egypt
Mr. Kenneth Speir, of the Midland Railway, has been apointed Secretary to the President of the Egyptian State Railways.

Our London Correspondent sends us by mail further particulars of the reception held at 22 Charles-street, Berkeley-Square, by Mr. and Mrs. Royle on Wednesday last, on the occasion of the marriage of their daughter to Captain C.W. Maclean. The house was a mass of roses and white flowers, which were chosen for the decoration of the stairs and reception rooms, a most happy combination. There were present Lady Wingate, wife of the Sirdar, wearing a heliotrope toque with a smart dress, and Lady Rogers in pale blue, with lovely lace. Lady Llangattock was in a beige-colored lace gown and toque with touches of blue. Lady Palmer was very smart in mauve chiffon and lace, with picture hat of the same colour. Lady Gorst, in a white dress, wore a China blue hat, and osprey. Miss Gorst was in light silk, with a brown hat, and Mrs. Hunter relieved her black dress by a rose pink hat. Baroness Malortie was dressed in ivory silk and lace, with a little hyacinth toque, and Mrs. Cecil Snow, with a grey gown, wore a heliotrope hat. Mrs. Douglas Morice was in a pale violet dress with a lace hat trimmed with violet ribbon and flowers.

div.head: BRITISH BATTLESHIP TOWED.
div.p: Confirming my telegram of this morning, I learn that the battleship Vengeance, one of the four which have been here since Sunday night, has something seriously wrong with her machinery, which defect made it necessary for the Albion to tow her a considerable distance in the Malacca Straits. She is to leave at 2 p.m. in company with the Ocean, Cen turion, and Albion, and arrangements have been made by the Ocean to tow her as far as Malta, where necessary repairs will be effected.

div.head: CAPTAIN LEITGEB'S DEATH.
div.p: The death of Captain Leitgeb, the much respected agent of the Austrian Lloyd here, has plunged the town in mourning. All flags were half-mast yesterday and but little was talked of beyond the death of this gentleman. Capt. LEitgeb served some 15 years at sea in the Austrian Lloyd vessels, and has represented his company here for many years.

div.head: THE TALE OF THE S.S. CALCHAS
div.p: The Holt Line S.S. Calchas, which came out of the Canal at 10 a.m. to-day, is now on her first homeward voyage after her capture, some five months ago, by the Russians. It appears that she was nearing the end of her voyage outwards, her destination being Yoko hama, and had a certain quantity of cotton and mails on board, both of which had been declared absolute contraband. The vessel,m with the same captain on board as now com mands the ship, was taken to Vladivostock and there guarded with a prize crew over four months in practically the depth of winter. Her entire crew were kept by her under a Russian guard, which treated them in many ways by no means well. The cold was intense, but none of the ship's people appear to have suffered or to have been any the worse for their long stay. The Court at Vladivostok decided that the vessel was a legal prize and intended confiscating her, but eventually merely removed all her contraband and allow ed her to proceed to China, from which coun try she brings the first of the season's teas. She will leave at 4 p.m.

div.head: GOVERNMENT HOSPITAL.
div.p: I have it on good authority that the Egyp tian Hospital, until now managed by a staff of male nurses and Sisters of Mercy, is to have in the near future a matron and four English nurses permanently attached to the institution, in much the same manner as obtains at the British Hospital here now. The hospital has been much improved and is to-day one of the best in the country

div.head: ARRIVAL OF SALVAGE VESSEL.
div.p: On the 15th inst., a tug-boat called the Flamant, towing the Champenois, a 300-ton lighter, caused some little surprise by coming in from sea and anchoring in the port. It was at first supposed that the lighter was towed here for ordinary commercial purposes, but I learn now that the Flamant and her consort are here as the result of consider able thought on the part of a private firm, and that they are intended for salvage work. It will surprise many to learn that not a single properly equipped salvage vessel is owned by the Canal Company and that in almost every case of need of late years, outside aid has been required to salve badly damaged ships, ignoring the cases of ships merely aground.

The sharp break in South Africans and the general weakness at the end of last week have been followed by an almost equally quick reaction. The settlement, which concluded yesterday, having gone through practically without a hitch, has helped largely to restore confidence to markets, as well as a report in Paris that a very strong combination is being formed by the greater groups, Messrs. Wernher, Beit, Eckstein, L. Hirsch & Co., Neumann, and the Central Mining Trust, with a view to defeating the market tactics of the Barnato group, and also with the possible end in view of buying up the Barnato interests, who, it is beliefved, would not be altogether averse to withdrawing from Citiy finance at the present juncture.

The appointment of M. Witte as the Russian representative at Washington is taken as a marked step in the direction of peace, negotia tions for which look like being commenced next month in earnest. The success of the new Japanese 4 1/2% loan, taken in conjunction with the admitted failure to raise a small internal loan in Russia, must also help towards an early conclusion of the war.

The gilt-edged market is a decidedly good one, and the present moment should offer good opportunities to the genuine investor. Public interest in the mining section is far too small yet for any marked improvement to be pro bable. The market is too much in the hands of outside manipulators, and, in addition to this, many dealers have had to be helped of late, which must constitute a certain source of weakness.

There has been a rally in the Egyptian min ing section this week, where some well-informed buying has been seen. Nile Valleys certainly look a tempting lock-up at 1 1/8, and United Africans at 1 5/16. A feature yesterday was the rise in Egyptian Mines to 15s. Land Bank shares are steady. Agricultural Banks keep very firm at 13 7/8 on the issue of 243,000 new shares to the present holders share for share at par-£5-which constiutes a very hand some bonus. Nationals are steady at 26 3/8, other shares showing little or no change in price.
In Egyptian cotton the business has been very limited, the higher ptrices having quite checked the demand. Quotations remain without change.
In Futures a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest values

American Futures. The Market this week has been exceedingly active, and prices have been subject to frequent and violent fluc tuations. To-day's closing values are 27 to 30 points below the highest rates touched. The extreme advance was due to renewed bad weather conditions, and heavy manipulation, chiefly in the American markets, but also to some extent here; the subsequent decline, to improved weather report, to heavy reali sations, and to the growing impression that the disastrous state of the crop has been much exaggerated. The trade here, and in America, has been seriously and adversely affected by the suddenness and magnitude of the late advance, and spinners are now purchasing their minimum requirements. We cannot venture any opinion. All the markets are in a feverish and dangerous state, and it will evidently require regular and favora ble weather conditions to hold speculation in check.
The following are the closing quotations:-
Players beat Gentlemen by 128 runs. The rest of the matches for this date have been drawn.
(Reuter.)

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE.
(Communication Officielle)
div.p: La Commission Municipale s'est réunie mercredi 19 Juillet 1905, à 4 h. 1/2 p.m., en séance de renvoi, sous la présidence de Mr. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: M.M. Abdel Moneim Bey Dalil, Zeky Bey Ghali, substitut du Procureur Général, A. Cumbo, T. Zuzzarini, Dr. Schiess bey, G. Zervudachi, membres A. Wilner, secrétaire p.i.
Les procès-verbaux de la Commission Muni cipale des 24 et 31 Mai 1905 sont approuvés.
Mention est faite de l'envoi aux membres des procès-verbaux des séances de la Déléga tion des 13 Juin au 27 Juin 1905.

Le Président dit, avant d'aborder l'ordre du jour, que par suite du départ en congé de plusieurs membres de la Délégation, il y aurait lieu de provoquer d'urgence une réunion de la Commission pour la nomination de deux mem bres suppléants provisoires à la Délégation, afin de ne pas retarder l'expédition des affaires courantes.
Une séance de la Commission est fixée à cet effet pour lundi 24 Juillet 1905, à 4. p.m.

Il est donné communication des lettres sui vantes: 1. d'une lettre du 21 Juin 1905, de S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur approuvant le projet d'accord avec l'entreprise Amalgià, arrêté par la Commission dans sa séance du 20 Mai 1905 et recommandant certaines me sures de précaution au sujet de l'installation provisoire d'une voie Decauville par l'entre prise, sur un partie des quais.
Le Président donne, à ce sujet, communica tion de l'échange de correspondance qui a eu lieu, en vertu de cette approbation avec l'entre prise Almagià, confirmant l'accord en question.

2. d'une lettre du 24 juin 1905 du Minis tère de l'Intérieur remettant l' arrêté sur les animaux et véhicules, adopté par la Commis sion le 31 mai 1905 et approuvé par le Conseil des Ministres dans sa séance du 22 juin 1905.

3. d'une lettre du 29 juin 1905 du Ministère de l'Intérieur remettant le projet de règlement d'application de la taxe sur les animaux et véhicules, arrêté par la Commission dans sa séance du 21 juin 1905 et faisaint part de quel ques modifications de pure forme, introduites au dit projet par le Contentieux du dit Minis tère.
Le Ministère est également d'avis de sup primer du dit projet le dernier alinée de l'art. 5, relatif à certaines dispositions concernant le transit des animaux en ville.
La Commission adopte les modifications suggérées par le Ministère et arrête le règle ment en conséquence.

4. d'une corresponance échangée avec la Cie des Eaux, au sujet des droits de la Munici palité dans la participation des bénéfices au delà du 10%, réalisés par cette Société pour l'exercice se terminant au 31 mars 1905 et de la remise par la Cie à la Ville d'une somme de £732-1-0, représantant la quote-part de la Municipalité dans la moitié du surplus des bénéfices réalisés.
5. d'une lettre du 29 juin 1905 de la Cie des Eaux annonçant l'achèvement des travaux de construction des nouveaux filtres.

Le Président expose, à ce sujet, que l'Ingé nieur en chef et l'Inspecteur Sanitaire ont été désignés pour opérer la réception des filtres et qu'ils ont remis un rapport concluant à ce que les travaux ont été exécutés dans les meilleures conditions.
Ce rapport figurera en annexe à un procès- verbal, sous impression, de la Délégation.

6. d'une lettre du 15 juillet 1905 du Minis tère de l'Intérieur, en réponse au voeu ex primé par la Commission, tendant à la révision du règlement pour les élections municipales du Collège des importateurs et d'après laquelle il ne serait pas d'avis de midifier le nouveau règlement, l'expérience n'en ayant pas encore démontré les inconvénients.
(à suivre).

div.head: L'Affaire Ninci-Dimaras
div.p: Nous apprenons que le 9 courant, à la Chambres des Députés hellénique, M. le Député Kantarzy a interpellé le Ministre des Affaires étrangères de Grèce au sujet des poursuites disciplinaires intentés par M.A. Ninic contre M. Constantin Dimaras, ancien président de la Cour d'Assises Hellénique de notre ville, re lativement à la conduite scandaleuse tenue par l'ex-magistrat pendant son séjour à Alexandrie.
Les journaux d'Athènes drelatant la susdite interpellation annoncent que M. le Ministre à déclaré qu'il s'occupait de l'affaire et que justice serait rendue.

div.head: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
div.p: Le marché est soutenu, mais peu animé. Les seules valeurs qui aient donné lieu à quelques transactions sont le Comptoir, la Banque Natio nale, l'Agricole et les Estates.
De 4 1/2 le Comptoir a haussé jusqu'à 4 5/8 pour finir acheteurs à 4 1/2. La Part de Fonda teur est évaluée de 35 à 40 livres sterling.
En hausse le Crédit Foncier de 815 à S.S. la Land Bank de 9 5/16 à 9 3/8, la Delta Land de 2 7/16 à 2 1/2, les Markets de 23 à 23/3, et la Nungovic très demandée à 9 9/16.
Par contre le Trust est plus faible à 1 3/8, la Delta Laight à 12 15/16, les Privilégiées Tramways à 162 1/2 et la Ramleh Railway à 7 3/16.

div.head: COLLEGE ST. FRANCOIS-XAVIER
div.p: La distribution solenelle des prix au Col lège St. François-Xavier a eu lieu hier après midi sous la présidence de M. Maurice Cam pana, consul suppléant de France à Alexandrie. De nombreuses notabilités y assistaient.

Après l'exécution de la Marseillaise et de l'hymne Khédivial, un group d'élèves a joué la comédie de Courteline "Le Commissaire est bon enfant" qui a obtenu un brillant et légitime succès. Les deux rôles principaux, ceux du Commissaire et de Floche, ont été admirable ment tenus, le premier par M. Kiven et le se cond par M.A. Deschizeaux. M. Amoric a été excellent dans le rôle de Breloc, M. Olphe Gaillard dans celui d'un Monsieur et MM. Lakah et Psalty en agents de police. Tous ont été remarqués pour leur bonne diction et la netteté de leur prononciation.

Après la pièce, le père Préfet a procédé à la lecture du palmarès. Treize élèves ont été reçus au baccaleuréat français, dont six pour la deu xième partie, lettres-philosophie,et sept pour la première, rhétorique. Ce sont MM. E. Cons tantino, E. Ganzoni, Ugo Giordana, H. Goubert, C. Lakah, L. Pangalo-A. Barrière, R. Gerin, H. Goubert, H. Hafez, H. Lopez, J. Neuville, et Apostolo Phronimos.

Le prix offert par les ancien élèves à celui qui a le mieux traité un sujet donné a été remporté par M.E. Constantino et le prix de langue française, offert par M.P. Girard à celui qui a fait la meilleure composition française, par M. René Gerin.

Les élèves dont les noms reviennent le plus fréquemment dans le palmarès sont en lettres- philosophie, MM. E. Constantino et Ugo Gior dana; en rhétorique, MM. Lopez et E. Gorra; en humanités, MM. A. Sepsi, M. Kiven, P. Olphe Galliard; en troisième, MM. Malatesta et P. Delenda; en quatrième, MM. M. Debbane et M. Gorra; en cinquième, MM. R. Daniel et J. Demetriadis; en sixi eme, MM. T. Malatesta et A. Kécati; en septième, MM. I. Pellegrini, B. Romanos, C. Ognianovich et Halim Ghali; en classe élémentaire, MM. G. Ghali, E. Roméo et S. de Serpos; en langue grecque, MM. Ve roudakis, A. Sepsi, P. Blanc, A. Aslan, J. Demi triadis; en langue arabe, MM. J. Lakah, Aziz Saab, A. Lopez, R. Daniel, A. Dupont; en dessin, MM. E. Robert, P. Saugeron, M. Amo ric, P. Blanc, A. Sepsi; en musique MM. U. Giordana et J. Lakah.
La rentrée des classes et fixée au 2 octobre pour les pensionnaires et au 3 octobre pour les demi-pensionnaires et les externes.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
NOTICE.
div.p: The Board hereby gives notice to the public that the Administration requires 40 pupils- 20 from Upper Egypt and 20 from Lower Egypt-who will be trained for the Traffic service with a view to their being appointed to Station duties in Upper or Lower Egypt. Competitive examinations for the admission of pupils to fill these vacancies will be held on and after the 25th July instant, before a Special Commission at Assiout Railway Station for those of Upper Egypt, and at Cairo for those of Lower Egypt.
Candidates must fill the following conditions:-

1st-They must be of Egyptian nationality; 2nd-They must be of good character; 3rd-They must possess the primary certi ficate of education of a date not previous to 1901; 4th-They must be medically fit for Rail way service; 5th-They must be between the age of 18 and 22 years; 6th-On being admitted, candidates must sign an engagement that they will work either in Upper or Lower Egypt during the whole or part of their service, as may be ordered by the Administration; 7th-Pupils will receive P.T. 7 per day each during the peirod allowed for studying tele graphy and will receive higher pay when they have the telegraph certificate, when they will be absorbed in the staff of the stations; 8th-If duiring the period of apprenticeship pupils do not give satisfaction, they will be dismissed and will not ahve the right to any claim whatever; 9th-Candidates attending the examination will pay their railway fares either to Assiout or to Cairo. Those, however, who are afterwards accepted will be granted a free pass to the place where they are sent for their apprentice- ship.
Candidates desirous of attending the above examination, are required to send their names to the Traffic Manager before 22nd instant, enclosing at the same time the following certificates:-

1-A certificate of good conduct signed by the Mamour of their district and the Omdeh of their parish; 2-The customary guarantees; 3-Those from Upper Egypt should produce certificates that they actually belong to Upper Egypt, and those of Lower Egypt should get certificates that they belong to Lower Egypt.
On the production of the above, their names will be recorded and an entrance card sent to them by the Traffic Manager.

Candidates presenting themselves at the place of examination will first of all be required to undergo an examination as to medical fitness, and not be allowed to proceed further with the examination unless they qualify in this.
The 40 candidates, who in the opinion of the Board of Examination are the best fitted as regards characters and both physical and mental acquirements, will be appointed élèves of the Administration.
Cairo, 10th July, 1905.

div.head: In the Estate of J. H. CLINTON-BAKER, Deceased.
div.p: I HEREBY give notice that all creditors and other persons having any debt claim or demand against the estate of the late JOHN HUGH CLINTON-BAKER, deceased (who died on the 4th day of March 1905 and whose will was provided on the 6th day of April 1905 by Henry William Clinton-Baker one of the executors therein named) should send in par ticulars of such debt claim or demand to me the solicitor for the said executors on or before the 1st day of September 1905 after which date the executors will proceed to distribute the estate among the persons entitled thereto either as legatees or otherwise having regard only to debts claims and demands on which they shall have had notice on or before the said 1st day of September 1905 and the executors shall not be liable for any debts claims or demands of which they shall not have had notice at that date.
Dated 19th July 1905.
L. CARTON DE WIART, Avocat
CAIRO.

div.head: THE UNLEAVENED FACT.
div.p: Offer him what you will of fancy's wares, ideas that would set a Latin race in revolution, dreams that a Celtic people would follow as a child chases a butterfly, John Bull but shakes his head. He is to be charmed only by solid, blue-book fact. Herein lies the secret of his power in the world.

After all, he will tell you, a fact is a fact- just as business is a business. It is tangible to the mind as a pewter-pot is to the hand. It doesn't even want proving; though the fact that it is capable of proof is, of course, in its favor. Fiction is all very well in your leisure hours; so is play-acting. Poetry, art, and all that sort of thing has its place-a small one. But when you come to deal with life as it is, real, everyday life, what have you to reckon with but facts? You can't get away from them.

John Bull is right. You can't get away from them. That is the trouble about facts. To escape them one must cross the Channel- the English Channel or St.George's. Thousands make the escape every year, and rightly call it a holiday. For the real explanation of the liking that the English have for the society of the French and the Irish-though they would not admit the explanation and often conceal the liking-is founded not on common but contrasting interests. The French evade fact, and the Irish have an airy disregard for it. Those of us - and they are many - who consciously or unconsciously are weary of the national idol as the Greeks were of their too just statesman, snatch fearful joy from the contemplation of Gallic and Gaelic defiance of fact. We do not understand it, but it amuses us and refreshes us.

There is nothing so piquant in our relations with our cousins the Germans. They, like us, are fact-worshippers, and our attitude towards one another is one of respect sometimes touched by boredom. We are all the while "odiously" comparing each other's possessions, measuring national incomes, navies, chimneys, generals, exports, throwing facts and figures at each other's heads, talking the same unvarying shop. The French are all for an idea, a joke, an emotion, a cry-the monarchy, the Republic the Commune, perficious Albion, vive l'Angleterre! Liberty Fraternity, Equality! -and noting too concrete or too permanent. It is not good business, but it is life. And when it does not shock John Bull it vastly diverts him. To be at one with the Fatherland has the calm of domestication, but to be friends with Madame France has the charm of flirtation.

One fears that the Irish do not sufficiently esteem fact. They scarcely have enough of it to make both ends meet, and John Bull thinks them the funniest people in the world. But their compensations are great. Despite all his artistic "ochones" over Ireland, the individual Irishman, wherever you find him, has the gift of happiness. He knows how to dispense with the inessential, and it takes a world of fact to spoil his wit or the cheerful current of his life. English visitors to Ireland at the time of the Gordon Bennet motor races were greatly entertained by local life in Kildare. The little town was for a week in a state of unwonted and bewildered importance. It was at midnight, after a day of the great race, when the streets were still thronged, that a window was thrown up, and a picturesquely clad Irishman appeared before the public. "Men of Kildayrr and the surrounding disthricts!" he cried, and returned into the seclusion, presumably, of his bed. The speech was short, perhaps, but it seemed completely to satisfy the speaker and the mul titude. The voice, hoarse with emotion, and the parting, expressive wave of the hand spoke the requisite volumes. But what an opport unity for an Englishman! One can fancy the heads of his prosy rhetoric. "Mr. Mayor, ladies, and gentlemen...auspicious occasion ...fine day...splendid roads... magnificent motor-cars...vehicles of the future...town and trade of Kildare."
It was at the same season that a tiresom, law-biding Englishman had occasion to ask an Irish policeman whether there were no licensing laws in the country.

"Yes, sorr," was the answer, "there's licensing laws. Oh I think so." "Then why don't you turn the people out of the public-houses after closing time?" The Irishman wondered at the visitor's simplicity. "Why, sorr," he said, "it would be so much trouble for us all!"

The answer, and the state of affairs it reveals, are chiefly amusing to the Briton because they are so shocking. To the English policeman law is a solid fact, one of the things that the mind can pick up, put in the scales, and hit with a hammer. He holds that the public were made for the law. To do him justice, he would stand in a puddle all night if there were a chance of arresting a cyclist riding on a disused footpath. Such a sense of duty is not to be despised. In bygone days gallant stupidity has brought on the whole less disaster than glory to British arms. But in the piping days of peace it leaves life a little dull.

The Americans are as great worshippers of fact as we ourselves, and even more conse quently successful. But a boyish strain of humour is a redeeming feature of all trans- Atlantic solemnity. In this respect the chief difference between the Irish and the American is that the former are unconscious and the latter conscious humorists. The Irishman is witty by instinct, the American by grace. The land of Mark Twain deserves that the story should be true which says that the big hotels maintain an official known as the Scapegoat Clerk. It is delightful to think that the manager of such a serious business as a hotel, to appease an irate guest, will repeatedly go through the farce of storming at and dismissing on th espot an apologetic, unhappy-looking subordinate, who acts his part with equal gusto in return for a weekly salary. An Englishman may not smile in business hours. An American is apparently not under the same restriction. That may explain the fact that Jonathan is able to work not only as hard, but longer than John.

We may continue to grow rich and potent, but we shall never be Merrie England again until we have caught something of French and Irish contempt for unleavened fact. There is no need to go to extremes. There must be a happy mean between solidity and inanity, between blue-books and musical comedy. But popular taste has yet to find it.

div.head: THE COTTON DISCLOSURES.
SECRETS CONVEYED BY MOVING A WINDOW SHADE.
div.p: It is by no means certain that the report of Mr. Wilson, the American Secretary for Agriculture, will complete the revelations as to the leakage of the cotton crop estimates. Now, as before, the insinuations dwarf the actual disclosures, even though the facts revealed have warranted the dismissal of a responsible Government official at Washington.

Apart from the statistician Holmes, Mr. Theodore Price is the only person named in the affair who is of sufficient importance to be mentioned abroad. Mr. Price states that he regards the inclusion of his name in the allega tions as libellous, and says he is amazed that the officials should have published their char ges without first communicating them to him. He threatens to institute legal proceedings in order to prove that he never saw or knew or acted with the conspirators, directly or in- directly.

The persons alleged to be concerened in procuring the advance information from the Agri cultural Department are insignificant indi viduals. They are not even known to the officials of that institution. Their reply to the charge consists of allegations of betrayal of confidence and also suppression of facts. They threaten to make disclosures which will implicate Secretary Wilson, and paralyse the Department's futre usefulness.

The returns were tabulated in a locked room, the key of which Secretary Wilson kept in his pocket. It appears that the official ac complice in the consipiracy communicated with persons outside by moving the window shade up and down. Sufficient information was signalled in this manner to enable the conspi rators to make profitable purchases and sales.

The gains of the official who communicated the information were covered by pretexts of legitimate business transactions. One of these was a partnership, and another was an interest in a mining property for 73,000 dols.

The disclosures give no reason to alter the present estimates of the cotton crop. With regard to the Department's methods of esti mating, the case stands as before. Where the facts cannot be exactly ascertained, the De partment's reports are based on opinions. Some of the private estimates are regarded as of equal authority with the Government's, and of these some agree with the official one and some do not.

div.head: FRANCE AND THE KAISER
div.p: Many explanations have been put forward for the sudden change of front made by the Kaiser over the question of France and Mo rocco, and for his acceptance of this Anglo- French Agreement last year, and his refusal to accept it this year. It is generally held that the one and only reason was the collapse of Russia in the Far East, which removed from Germany all fear of a diversion on her Eastern frontier, should she make her self disagreeable to France. But the "Con temporary Review" puts forward the sugges tion , which is quite ingenious, that the Kaiser originally approved of the Anglo-French Agree ment because he thought that France was about to set out on a costly wild-goose chase in Morocco, which would force her to keep a large force locked up in Africa to the detri ment of her activity in Europe. But then M. Delcassé announced his policy of "pacific penetration," which greatly disappointed the Kaiser, as it would neither bind France's hand, nor drain her resources. Almost at the same time the battle of Mukden was fought and won by Japan, and Russia ceased to be a factor in European politics. It therefore became safe, as well as expedient, to reverse the German policy of last year, and to proclaim that the Anglo-French Agreement contained stipulations contrary to German commercial interests. There is no doubt that the Kaiser would gladly see France entangled in Morocco, but it is safe to say that he would not have moved had not Russia been hopelessly defeated in Manchuria, and so eliminated from Euro pean politics.

div.head: ICELAND'S NEW ATTRACTION.
div.p: Iceland has been heated-not by an erup tion of Hecla or another visit from a British novelist in search of freh material, but by the receipt of its first telegram. Till June 28 last news had come to the country only by steamer. The land had therefore remained comparatively peaceful, distractions being few and invitations to take a share in the uproar of the outside world so far between as to be ignored. But now all this is changed. Iceland comes into the running. It recog nised the fact by getting tremendously ex- cited over the first budget of red-hot news. What the consequences may be no man knoweth. It may well be prophesied, however, that Iceland will become more popular as a holiday resort. For some time past its guests have been increasing, and the arrival of the telegraph removes th elast barrier to their approach. As for the climate, that need prevent nobody from taking the trip. In the south, we find, it is somewhat like that of the north of Scotland-rather wet and change able. There are occasional thunderstorms, as in England, while carrots, cabbages, and potatoes thrive very well. What more can a holiday-maker ask?

div.head: FAITS CRIMINELS II.-DELITS
(Suite)
3e Cassation en matière pénale.
div.p: Les pourvois reçus par le Parquet de la Cour d'Appel en 1904 se sont élevés à 3.094, contre 3.293 en 1903. On dirait une différence in significante, mais quand on examine les détails, on la trouve au contraire très significante.
Pour bien comprendre cette question il faut remonter à l'année 1899.

Avant cette date, vu que les codes no pré cisaient pas que le pourvoi en cassation et le délai du pourvoi étaient suspensifs, comme ils le décident pour le recours par voie d'appel (ancien code d'instruction criminelle, articles 151, 179 et 216), on ne sursoyait pas à l'exé cution des arrêts de la Cour et des jugements rendus en appel par les tribunaux du centre. Mais en 1899, les cours d'appel et de cassations ont jugé que le pourvoi en cassation était sus pensif de l'exécution. Comme il fallait obtem pérer à cette jurisprudence et que, d'autre part, les difficultés qui en résultaient étaient insur montables, le Gouvernement a cru devoir pren dre des mesures législatives. En effet, un décret du 19 juin 1900 disposa que le pourvoi en cassa tion n'est suspensif que quand le condamné n'a pas subi de détention préventative relativement à l'affaire sur laquelle porte le pourvoi. Ce décret, tout en réglant la question au point de vue légal, occasionna une augmentation du nombre des pourvois formés par des inculpés qui n'a vaient pas subi de détention préventive et qui voulaient différer autant que possible l'exécution de leur peine...

C'est au 15 avril 1904 qu'est entré en vigueur le nouveau Code d'Instruction criminelle, d'après lequel le pourvoi en cassation n'est plus suspensif d'exécution qu'en cas de condamna tion à mort. Or, des 2.485 pourvois en matière de délit, faits en l'année 1904, 1.307 ont été faits jusqu'au 14 avril, c'est-à-dire sous le ré gime de l'ancien code, et 1.178 du 15 avril jusqu'à fin décembre, c'est-à-dire que si le régime de l'ancien code s'était étendu sur toute l'année, on a le droit de supposer que les pourvois en matière de délits seuls se seraient portés au chiffre énorme de 4.488: tandis que sous le nouveau code ces pourvois n'auraient été que de 1.656. En d'autres termes, la pro portion des pourvois en matière de délits s'est diminuée du 37% sous l'empire du nouveau code.

En même temps ce changement dans la loi semble avoir réagi sur les pourvois en matière de crime, quoiqu'il n'y ait rien dans ce change ment de nature à influer directement sur cette question, les accusés de crimes étant presque toujours en détention préventive. Quoiqu'il en soit, les pourvois en matière de crime jusqu'au 14 avril étaient de 207: et de cette date jusqu'à fin décembre ils étaient de 402, au lieu de 720 comme ils auraient dû l'être d'après la proportion donnée.
Il reste à voir quel sera l'effet de l'institut ion des Cours d'assises sur les pourvois en matière de crime; mais je serais porté à croire que la tendance sera dans la direction d'une décroissance.

Le tableau n. 10 donne le résultat des pourvois accueillis. Sur 15 arrêts rectifiant l'application de la loi, 6 ont été rendus sur pourvoi du Parquet. Seulement 9 pourvois for més par les prévenus et les parties civiles ont abouti à une rectification de l'application de la loir. Restent 155 affaires dans lesquelles il y a eu cassation avec renvoi pour nullité substan tielle de la procédure ou de la sentence.

div.head: V. Execution des jugements definitifs et arrets en matiere de crimes, delits et contraventions.
div.p: Les jugements rendus pendant l'année 1904, s'élèvent à 191.749 dont 163.237 en premier degré, 24.909 au second degré, 3.606 cassa tions.

Sur ce nombrr 162.602 jugements de con damnation sont devenus définitifs, dont 1.168 dans les affaires criminelles, 65 072 dans les affaires de délits et 96.362 dans les affaires de contraventions. Outre ces 162.602 juge ments il en restait encore 18.340 inexécutés de l'année passée.
Du total de ces deux chiffres, total qui s'élève à 180.942, 164.994 ont été exécutés et il restait au 31 décembre 1904, 15.948 à exécuter soit 9%
Le nombre des jugements et arrêts rendus en 1903 s'est élevé à 182.160 dont 139.572 jugements de condamnation définitifs. Il restait au 31 décembre 1903, 18.340 jugements à exécuter, soit 13%

Des jugements de condamnation rendus par les tribunaux de premier degré, 12.061 ont permis la suspension de l'exécution sous cau tion. Dans 2.004 de ces derniers la caution a été payée et l'exécution effectivement suspen due. Les 10.059 autres furent exécutés faute de paiement de la caution.

Quand au nombre des personnes condamnées à des peines pécuniaires (y compris les frais), le nombre qui les a payées et le total des sommes payées, je trouve opportun d'insérer ici quelques détails en forme de table, pour la commodité de comparaison entre les chiffres des années 1903 et 1904.
En effet, la nouvelle législation d'un côté, et les instructions émanant du Ministère de la Justice d'un autre côté, ont eu une forte in fluence sur cette question.

En premier lieu, les guges ont accepté en g;enéral les vues émises par le Ministère de la Justice, qui a fait remarquer que les condam nations à des emprisonnements très courts n'ont pas eu en général un effet très repressif, et ne servent qu'à remplir les prisons inutile ment. De cela il arrive que beaucoup plus de personnes ont été condamnées à des amendes pour la plupart assez légères.

En deuxième lieu, les détails de la loi sur la contrainte par corps ont été changés d'une manière qui est plus apte à contraindre en effet les condamnés à payer.
Troisièmement, le changement dans la loi d'après lequel les condamnations pécunitaires sont toujours exécutoires nonobstant appel, a influé dans le même sens.
Les chiffres sont comme suit:
Anée 1903. Nombre des condamnés à des peines pécuniaires 106.781, dont: 34.881 ont payé; 37.038 ont travaillé; 64.862 ont été em prisonnés...
Année 1904: Nombre des condamnés à des peines pécuniaires 170.453 dont: 79,457 ont payé, 70,016 ont travaillé, et 20,980 ont été emprisonnés.

Le juge n'est plus comme sous le régime de l'ancien Code, tenu à condamner l'inculpé reconnu coupable à tous les frais. Il est laissé à sa discrétion de le condamner à tout ou partie des frais, ou de ne pas le condamner aux frais du tout...
L'article 254 porte que lorsqu'un inculpé n'est condamné qu'à une partie des frais, le montant de la condamnation sera liquidé dans le jugement.

On trouve que dans la période du 15 avril jusqu'à fin décembre 1904 les juge ments de condamnation dans lesquels les frais ont été mis à la charge des pré venus s'élèvent à 42.768 dont 75 en matière de crimes, 8.417 en matière de délits et 34.376 en matière de contraventions. De ce chiffre de 42.768, les frais ont été liquidés dans 39.579 jugements et dans 3.189 les frais n'ont pas été liquidés.
Les jugements dans lesquels les frais n'ont pas été mis à la charge des prévenus s'élèvent à 64.816 dont 857 en matière de crimes, 27.914 en matière de délits et 36.045 en matière de contraventions.

Cela veut dire que les jugements dans les quels les frais ont été liquidés, par rapport au total des jugements dans lesquels les frais ont été mis à la charge des prévenus, sont d'en viron 93%; et les jugements dans lesquels les frais n'ont pas été mis à la charge des pré venus, par rapport au total des jugements de condamnation, sont de 60%

div.head: VI.-Prisons et detention preventive.
div.p: Pendant l'année 1904, le nombre d'incarcé rations nouvelles dans les prisons ordinaires s'élèvent à 102.869 et le nombre des mises en liberté à 96.042.
Ces chiffres sont inférieurs à ceux de l'année 1903 pendant laquelle le nombre d'incarcéra tions et de mises en liberté s'est élevé respecti vement à 104,160 et 97,791.
Pendant l'année, le nombre des personnes qui ont été detenues pour le compte de l'ins truction s'est élevé à 13,417, chiffre inférieur à celui de l'année 1903 où il était de 14,910.
Le nombre des personnes qui ont été déte nues en matière de flagrant délit s'est élevé à 10,925, chiffre inférieur à celui de 1903 où il était de 12,163.

div.head: I.-Tribunaux de premiere instance
div.p: Pendant le cours de l'année, 2,307 affaires nouvelles ont été présentées aux tribunaux de première instance.

Sur ce nombre 1,276 avaient pour objet des contestations personelles ou mobilières et 1,031 avaient pour objet des contestations immobilières. Ce nombre est supérieur à celui de l'année 1903 où il était de 2,255, à celui de 1902 où il était de 1,818 et à celui de 1901 où il était de 1,883.
Le total des affaires terminées, y compris celles arriérées de l'anné 1903, s'est élevé à 1.682.

div.head: Assistance judiciaire.
div.p: Le nombre des demandes d'assistance judi ciaire examinées devant ces tribunaux a été de 396. Sur ce nombre 192 ont été admises et 204 rejetées.

div.head: II.-Tribunaux gommaires
div.p: Pendant le cours de l'année, 97.963 affaires nouvelles, civiles, ont été présentées aux tri bunaux de justice sommaire. Sur ce nombre 78.312 avaient pour objet des contestations personelles et 19.653 avaient pour objet des contestations immobilières.
Sous le rapport de l'importance, les affaires se divisaient en 76.260 ayant une valeur ne dépassant pas 1.000 P.T. et 21.705 d'une valeur soit supérieure à 1.000 P.T. soit indé terminée.
Le total des affaires terminées, y compris celles arrières de l'année 1903, s'est élevé à 94 662...

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Telegraph Department, Sudan Govern ment, is in need of a number of boys for training in the Telegraph school at Khartoum to eventually become telegraphists.
Applicants should be under 16 years of age, and in possession of the Primary or an equiva lent education certificate.

Applicants for these vacancies should be sent to the Office of the Agent General, Sudan Government, War Office, Cairo, enclosing birth certificate and any other certificate of charac ter or education.

On receipt of these, should it be decided that applicants are suitable, they will be medically examined to find out whether they are medically fit for service in the Sudan, and when passed fit they will be given free pass from Cairo to Khartoum.

On arrival at Khartoum they will remain for three months under probation, joining with rate of pay at P.T.5 per day. On appointment as assistants they will receive £2 per month, and on appointment as telegraphists, £4 per month.
In case candidates prove unsatisfactory after passing the probationary period, they would be granted a free pass from Khartoum to Shellal only.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital.
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five pounds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of the Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes at the price of Five Pounds sterling per share, payable on application.
Application should be made:-
in EGYPT to the Head office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria.
in LONDON to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividend from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to exercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz: £5 per share.
The President of the Board of Directors, (signed) Elwin Palmer.
Cairo, the 8th July 1905.
